text: Arrow.jl does support Tables.jl interface, but it is missing from the list of integrations: <https://github.com/JuliaData/Tables.jl/blob/main/INTEGRATIONS.md>

text:
I created a PR <https://github.com/JuliaData/Tables.jl/pull/227>
A lot of new packages have a direct dependency as releaved by the `find_integrations.jl`

elements.text: A lot of new packages have a direct dependency as releaved by the

text:
The thing is, this list is not that useful as it doesn’t reveal what kind of integration the packages have with Tables.jl.
Parquet.jl can write to parquet from a Tables.jl interface, but it cannot read from Parquet to Tables.jl. It can create a DataFrame because the output it provides is acceptable to DataFrame, but it’s not Tables.jl interface that it uses, it’s a Dict.

elements.text:
The thing is, this list is not that useful as it doesn’t reveal what kind of integration the packages have with Tables.jl.
Parquet.jl can write to parquet from a Tables.jl interface, but it cannot read from Parquet to Tables.jl. It can create a DataFrame because the output it provides is acceptable to DataFrame, but it’s not Tables.jl interface that it uses, it’s a Dict.

text: As Tables.jl supports `rowaccess` and `columnaccess`, it’s conceivable that two packages would be unable to understand each other even though they support Tables.jl if they support different subsets of the interface.

elements.text: , it’s conceivable that two packages would be unable to understand each other even though they support Tables.jl if they support different subsets of the interface.
